# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is how you can define the `timezone_bumper` function in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumber(dt::DateTime, bump=3)
    dt + Hour(bump)
end

# Testing
println(timezone_bumber(Dates.now())) # It will print the current time with 3 hours added
```
This function `timezone_bumper` takes a DateTime type and an optional integer argument, `bump`. If the bump argument is not provided, it defaults to 3.

The `Hour(bump)` part of code increases the given datetime object by `bump` hours.

If you try to pass a Date type instead, Julia will throw an error because Date and DateTime are different types in Dates package of Julia.

```julia
println(timezone_bumber(Dates.today())) # It will throw an error
```
